article_title: German Stocks Rise Most in a Month, Led by Steelmakers, Daimler
article_text: LISTEN TO ARTICLE    5:12      SHARE THIS ARTICLE   Share   Tweet   Post   Email  {"contentId":"KTJZTA0UQVI901","position":"brokerboxarticle","dimensions":{"large_desktop":[[120,60]],"small_desktop":[[120,60]],"tablet":[[120,60]]},"strategy":"viewable","positionIncrement":1,"targeting":{"position":"brokerboxarticle1","url":"/news/articles/2009-11-23/german-stocks-rise-most-in-a-month-led-by-steelmakers-daimler"},"containerId":"brokerboxarticle-u7exSQf"}   German stocks climbed the most in a month as reports showed sales of existing U.S. homes jumped to the highest level since 2007 and European services and manufacturing industries expanded.    ThyssenKrupp AG and Salzgitter AG, the country’s largest steelmakers, rallied with metals prices. Daimler AG, the world’s second-biggest maker of luxury cars, rose 2 percent as its Mercedes-Benz division forecast Chinese sales will increase. Banks also advanced.    {"contentId":"KTJZTA0UQVI901","position":"outstream","dimensions":{"large_desktop":[[1,8]],"small_desktop":[[1,8]],"tablet":[[1,8]]},"strategy":"always","type":"Outstream Video Native Ad","targeting":{"position":"outstream","url":"/news/articles/2009-11-23/german-stocks-rise-most-in-a-month-led-by-steelmakers-daimler"},"containerId":"outstream-video-1-KTJZTA0UQVI901"}   {"contentId":"KTJZTA0UQVI901","position":"outstream","dimensions":{"mobile":[[1,8]]},"strategy":"always","type":"Outstream Video Native Ad","targeting":{"position":"outstream","url":"/news/articles/2009-11-23/german-stocks-rise-most-in-a-month-led-by-steelmakers-daimler"},"containerId":"outstream-video-2-KTJZTA0UQVI901"}   The benchmark DAX Index added 2.4 percent to 5,801.48, the steepest gain since Oct. 14. The measure has climbed 58 percent from this year’s low on March 6 as companies reported better-than-estimated earnings and the country’s economy unexpectedly exited recession. The broader HDAX Index rose 2.5 percent today.    {"contentId":"KTJZTA0UQVI901","position":"box","dimensions":{"mobile":[[300,250],[3,3],[1,1],"fluid"]},"type":"Mobile Body Box Ad","positionIncrement":1,"targeting":{"position":"box1","positionIncrement":1,"url":"/news/articles/2009-11-23/german-stocks-rise-most-in-a-month-led-by-steelmakers-daimler"},"containerId":"box-vasqpl0"}   “After last week’s disappointing housing data, today’s report was eagerly awaited,” said Ralf Piersig, an equity analyst at LGT Capital Management in Pfaeffikon, Switzerland. “In terms of economic numbers it has been a successful day for equity markets.”    The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing U.S. homes climbed 10.1 percent in October to an annual pace of  {"contentId":"KTJZTA0UQVI901","position":"desktop-in-article1","dimensions":{"large_desktop":[[5,4]],"small_desktop":[[5,4]]},"type":"Desktop in article Native Ad","targeting":{"position":"desktop-in-article1","url":"/news/articles/2009-11-23/german-stocks-rise-most-in-a-month-led-by-steelmakers-daimler"},"containerId":"desktop-in-article-1-KTJZTA0UQVI901"}   6.1 million, the highest since February 2007. Separately, a composite index based on a survey of purchasing managers in both industries in the 16-nation euro area rose to 53.7 in November from 53 the prior month, according to Markit Economics.  Steelmakers Rally  ThyssenKrupp, Germany’s largest steelmaker, climbed 2.6 percent to 24.94 euros, while smaller rival Salzgitter increased  3.1 percent to 64.95 euros. Copper rallied to a 14-month high in London and prices of lead, nickel and zinc also increased.  {"contentId":"KTJZTA0UQVI901","position":"in-article1","dimensions":{"mobile":[[5,19],[300,250],[3,3],[1,1],"fluid"],"tablet":[[5,11],[728,90],[1,1]]},"type":"In Article Flex Native Ad","positionIncrement":1,"targeting":{"position":"in-article1","positionIncrement":1,"url":"/news/articles/2009-11-23/german-stocks-rise-most-in-a-month-led-by-steelmakers-daimler"},"containerId":"in-article-1-KTJZTA0UQVI901"}   Daimler climbed 2 percent to 35.67 euros. The automaker’s Mercedes-Benz division expects China to surpass the U.K. as its third-biggest market next year with its sales growth in the Asian country outpacing the overall auto market. Nationwide sales will rise by as much as 15 percent next year, Mercedes-Benz China head Klaus Maier said.  Deutsche Bank AG, the country’s largest bank, gained 3.9 percent to 50.95 euros, while Commerzbank AG added 1.7 percent to 6.67 euros. James Bullard, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, said yesterday he favors the U.S. central bank seeking authority to continue buying mortgage-backed bonds after the first quarter of next year to bolster bank liquidity.  The following shares rose or fell in Frankfurt. Stock symbols are in parentheses.   Douglas Holding AG (DOU GY) rallied 1.72 euros, or 5.5 percent, to 32.85, the steepest gain since March. Europe’s largest makeup and perfume retailer said Mueller Ltd. & Co. KG has informed the company that its stake has risen above 3 percent. Focus magazine reported earlier that Erwin Mueller, the billionaire owner of Germany’s fourth-largest drugstore chain, plans to lift his holding in Douglas to 18 percent.  Estavis AG (E7S GY) soared 14 cents, or 6.5 percent, to  {"contentId":"KTJZTA0UQVI901","position":"desktop-in-article2","dimensions":{"large_desktop":[[5,4]],"small_desktop":[[5,4]]},"type":"Desktop in article Native Ad","targeting":{"position":"desktop-in-article2","url":"/news/articles/2009-11-23/german-stocks-rise-most-in-a-month-led-by-steelmakers-daimler"},"containerId":"desktop-in-article-2-KTJZTA0UQVI901"}   2.29 euros, climbing for a second day. The real-estate company was raised to “buy” from “neutral” at WestLB AG, which said in a report the company “is guiding a positive result for the full year.”  Hochtief AG (HOT GY) rose 2.34 euros, or 4.3 percent, to 57, snapping a four-day drop. Germany’s biggest construction company’s Leighton unit has won a third order for work on the Gorgon gas project on Barrow Island, Australia. The total group order volume of the project is 561 million euros ($840 million), with Leighton’s share at about 421 million euros.  Infineon Technologies AG (IFX GY) increased 7.5 cents, or  {"contentId":"KTJZTA0UQVI901","position":"in-article2","dimensions":{"mobile":[[5,19],[300,250],[3,3],[1,1],"fluid"]},"type":"In Article Flex Native Ad","positionIncrement":1,"targeting":{"position":"in-article2","positionIncrement":1,"url":"/news/articles/2009-11-23/german-stocks-rise-most-in-a-month-led-by-steelmakers-daimler"},"containerId":"in-article-2-KTJZTA0UQVI901"}   2.4 percent, to 3.18 euros, ending two days of losses. Europe’s second-largest maker of semiconductors expects a profit in the current fiscal year because of lower costs and stronger demand for its computer chips, Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung reported, citing Chief Executive Officer Peter Bauer.  Phoenix Solar AG (PS4 GY) gained 1.33 euros, or 3.9 percent, to 35.50, the steepest advance this month. The company, which builds and operates solar plants, was raised to “add” from “neutral” at WestLB, which said in a report “we believe that the company’s sales growth will pick up strongly in the coming two quarters, because we anticipate an accelerating market for power plants in Germany.”  Vossloh AG (VOS GY), Germany’s biggest supplier of concrete railroad ties, rallied 4.62 euros, or 7 percent, to 70.97, the steepest gain since May. Equinet AG today reiterated its “accumulate” recommendation on the stock, saying the company is “well positioned to become a supplier” to Deutsche Bahn AG’s Qatar project, which “should open further opportunities for Vossloh in coming years.”   Published on ‎23‎ ‎November‎, ‎2009‎ ‎17‎:‎44        Have a confidential tip for our reporters?
